transcript.text: still to come on the NewsHour tonight a
conversation with gome Chomsky more on
the Arts funding debate and a Roger
rosenblat
essay next tonight another in our series
of special conversations on the Persian
Gulf crisis gome chumsky is Institute
professor of linguistics and philosophy
at the Massachusetts Institute of
Technology he's written numerous books
and articles over the past 20 years on
US foreign policy particularly on the
Middle East Professor chsky just
completed a book on the postc Cold War
system entitled deterring democracy he
joins us in public station WGBH in
Boston Professor Chomsky thank you for
joining us glad to be here listening to
uh the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister how
do you think Iraq's occupation of Kuwait
is going to be
resolved well there are uh it should
definitely be resolved with the U uh
removal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait at
the very least and there are three ways
in which that could happen uh it could
uh be done through the effects of uh of
the Embargo and other economic measures
uh a second possibility would be to do
it through war and a third possibility
would be to do it through
negotiations uh now the second
possibility War uh could be absolutely
catastrophic uh in unpredictable ways
the real there is a general consensus in
the world I think there little doubt of
that uh there's a hope that the first
method the uh uh the Embargo and related
measures will succeed uh the problem
arises and in fact divisions then begin
to surface uh when we ask about the
possibility in fact unfortunately
likelihood that the Embargo will not not
succeed in uh removing Iraq from Kuwait
then the choices become clear uh and in
fact they are already clear diplomacy or
war on that issue there's a good deal of
division that issue surfaced at the
Helsinki Summit and uh in fact on that
issue I think the as I read the uh
International situation the United
States is relatively isolated in uh
preferring the warlike
option um the uh first of all back to
the Embargo for a moment you sound very
pessimistic about the Embargo achieving
what uh President Bush and the security
and the United Nations hopes it will
achieve well I think that's hard to
predict that uh there it's it's by no
means a certainty that it's going to
work uh that it's quite possible that uh
over a couple of months the Embargo will
start to leak and there'll be various
evasions and so on I hope it'll work but
I think one can have very little
confidence in that are you impressed
with the this incident in the uh sort of
post Cold War order as an example of uh
of the world uniting against an
aggressor does that U which is what the
UN Charter hoped would happen is that
does that impress
you uh there is Unity against an
aggressor but I think it has virtually
nothing to do with the so-called postc
Cold War era uh there have been many uh
aggressions in that region and elsewhere
over the years uh the uh there has been
unfortunately
no rarely has there been unity in
opposing them and I should say that if
you look at the record you'll find that
the United States has very often uh
supported uh those aggressions or uh uh
and interfered with un efforts to stop
them and has helped maintain them but
this is being called the first crisis of
the postc Cold War era maybe it's
possible that it's being called that but
but that's not accurate uh the invasion
of Panama certainly qualifies as the
first military action of the so-called
postc Cold War era and how does that
equate with uh the Iraqi invasion of of
Kuwait in your view I don't think it
equates with it exactly but it was uh
the the invasion of Panama was rather
striking and that uh uh it was the first
example of U us aggression or subversion
in which there was no appeal made to
there was no pretext that we were uh
acting to defend ourselves against the
Russians or their agents and the reason
was that uh at that point this was this
pretext had never been credible but at
this point it was beyond the imagination
of anyone to invented in that respect it
was we might call it a post-cold war
Invasion beyond that there are there are
similarities I should say uh if uh uh
the uh this was a an act of direct
aggression it was condemned by the
United Nations uh the United uh the
United States had to vote against both
Security Council and uh General Assembly
resolutions uh it uh uh the the United
States established a uh puppet regime
which is dominated by us so-called
advisors down to details it reinstituted
the uh leadership group of its Choice uh
there there's plainly similarities to
the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait no too
historic I mean if it had not been for
the firm International response to the
Iraqi Invasion it's quite possible that
they would have left in a puppet regime
to serve their purposes which would have
made the invasion in no sense more
justifiable uh as in the case of any two
historical events there are also many
differences but at the level of
principle and of law uh the only
relevant difference is that uh in one
case we did it so it's regarded as
benign and in the other case they did it
so it's regarded as
nefarious what do you think of Mr Bush's
response to the Iraqi Invasion going
back nearly 6 weeks
now I think that uh the organization of
economic uh pressures and measures such
as the Embargo is definitely legitimate
in my view I think we should although we
have never adhered we've rarely adhered
to this in the past uh we and the world
should adhere to the principle that uh
acquisition of territory by force or the
use of force in international Affairs is
illegitimate and in fact unlawful uh so
that reaction was legitimate as for the
sending of troops uh I think you could
make a case for it I think there was
reason to believe that Iraq might have
been planning to move on to further
aggression uh beyond that point I think
serious questions arise and it's
precisely beyond that point point that
the US position tends to be quite
isolated in the world uh the uh the the
question beyond that point is uh do we
prepare for an eventuality in which we
will be uh driven to or we'll choose to
use military force or do we explore
diplomatic options uh a diplomatic track
uh do we move towards
multilateralization of the effort and so
on and so forth those are the crucial
questions and those are the ones on
which U uh the over that there was a
division at the Helsinki Summit and I
think it's generally the case that most
of the world supports uh the gbf's
position on that um just before we go on
with that um some conservatives one
faction of conservatives and we've had
uh at least one of them on this program
argue that um and they've been labeled
Neo isolationist for arguing it that
there was no vital us interest at stake
and that the United States should not be
playing World policemen and shouldn't
have sent troops in this case what what
do you feel about that well I I think it
is correct that the United States should
not be playing World policemen and of
course the United States like any other
power uh acts not on principle but in
its interests in this particular case
the interests happen to Accord with a
valid principle it would have made much
more sense uh for there to be and much
more proper for there to be a uh uh an
international response uh organized and
run by the United Nations uh whether
that could have been done one can raise
questions about I think it could
certainly be done now uh as for uh the
vital interest of the United States uh
one could debate it but the fact of the
matter is that it's been a leading
driving uh uh doctrine of US foreign
policy since the
1940s that the vast and unparalleled
energy resources of the uh uh the Gulf
region uh will be effectively dominated
by the United States and its clients and
crucially that no independent indigenous
force will be permitted to have a
substantial influence on the
administration of uh uh oil production
and price that's been a leading
principle of us policy since the 1940s
and I think it remains so as we see and
a valid a valid principle in your
view that principle is not a valid
principle in my view I don't see that
there's any justif there's no
justification for Iraq controlling uh
the administration of oil uh production
and price and there's no justification
in our controlling it MH um some have
argued again on this program uh that if
Saddam Hussein doesn't get out of Iraq
that there would be justification for
the US using Force to get him out or
further justification for the US using
Force to uh destroy his military
potential how do you feel about those
arguments I don't think that there is
any justification for the us to do it I
think there would be justification for
an international effort to do it in this
and numerous other cases in that region
and elsewhere uh where
territory has been acquired by force
where territories have been annexed
where there has been unlawful use of
force in world affairs uh sure it's
legitimate to enforce the principles of
the UN Charter I think they're good
principles we don't uphold them in fact
we've repeatedly violated them uh in
this particular instance as in every
instance they should be upheld and in
fact by the methods that are outlined in
the charter by uh uh by uh operations
conducted by the security Council
however I do think that it's a kind of a
diversion to raise that issue because
the real question again in my view is uh
whether uh we are must we move directly
to the eventuality of War are there
possibilities for well how do you answer
that how do you answer that latter
question where do you see what Avenue do
you see and through what issues that
might lead to a diplomatic or negotiated
settlement well there have been several
offers floated uh through August uh
several by Iraq some by others uh the
United States has rejected them forth
with without any consideration but some
of them U uh I think do offer the Poss
could be explored so for example on
August 12th uh Iraq proposed withdrawal
from Kuwait uh its withdrawal from
Kuwait in conjunction with the
withdrawal of military forces from all
occupied Arab territory that meant Syria
in Lebanon uh Israel in southern Lebanon
and in the occupied territories that was
rejected instantaneously without any
consideration although I should say in
England for example the U Financial
Times Conservative Business newspaper
while saying that the offer was
unacceptable nevertheless uh did say
that it it it provides a path that
should be followed away from disaster to
through negotiations again on uh August
23rd
uh Iraq uh uh made a proposal an Iraqi
proposal was transmitted to the white
house uh which uh looked very
forthcoming uh at least as to what what
we know about it which is very little uh
it proposed U uh a complete withdrawal
from U of Iraqi troops from Kuwait a
freeing of the hostages a termination of
sanctions uh the only concession no
precondition that the United States
should withdraw troops from the region
or any other precondition the only
concession to Iraq listed there uh was
that the rumala oil field uh which dips
slightly into quti territory it's mainly
Iraqi uh in a rather contested border
region that that should be handed over
to Iraq well once again that's uh uh I I
I wouldn't say one should say fine let's
accept that it's over uh but that does
seem to in fact that white house
specialist on Middle East Affairs was
quoted as saying that this offer is
negotiable and serious and I think that
that's correct that uh would looked like
a serious offer and there have there
have been some others there's there's
very little reporting about this so it's
hard to be certain but according to the
Israeli press uh there is a an offer
that originated apparently with the PLO
a text of it was quoted by uh F Hussein
can I we just have half a minute left
can I ask you do you think think if uh
if uh this is to be solved without
recourse to uh to military uh means that
one or other of those Avenues will in
the end have to be followed something
like that I think a compromise by to use
President Bush's words would have to be
accepted do you think I don't think it
would be much of a compromise there are
debatable issues there such as for
example the exploitation of the rila
field uh but I think that there are
negotiation negotiating that could be
pursued the same is true of the more
far-reaching question of the uh
destruction of Iraq's chemical and other
unconventional weapons capacity again
there is has been an offer on the table
which we rejected an Iraqi offer last
April
to eliminate their chemical and other
unconventional arsenals if Israel were
to simultaneously do the same to reject
it but I think that should be pursued as
well sorry to interrupt you I have to
end it there that's the of our time
Professor chsky thank you very much for

us
